p: Iran was among the first countries struck by the COVID-19 pandemic and is currently among the highest infection prevalence and mortality in the world ( World Health Organization, 2020a). People who use drugs (PWUD) and specifically those without homes have potentially higher probability of contracting and transmitting COVID-19 due to limited access to personal hygiene facilities and medical care, and suffering from underlying diseases ( United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, 2020; Volkow, 2020). This article focuses its attention on people who have often experienced several years of homelessness, injecting and high sexual risk behavior while residing in so-called ‘spots’ [ Patogh] located in streets and the margins of highways, parks, deserted buildings and temporary shelters ( Amin-Esmaeili, Rahimi-Movaghar, Gholamrezaei, & Razaghi, 2016). So it is important to ensure adequate access of low-threshold and COVID-19 services for people residing at ‘spots’.
